awd_titl_txt: EAGER: BRAIDING: Lattice engineered nonabelian defects in fractional Chern insulators
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: in the last decade, the possibility of utilizing unusual quantum statistics of emergent states of matter as a basis for quantum computation has gone from being a distant dream to an ambitious but reasonable possibility. Recent advances are based on assembly of required ingredients through proximity effects. In this approach, two materials with complementary properties are placed in close proximity to each other, for example allowing superconductivity to be introduced into materials which have complementary properties. Most prominently, Majorana bound states, the simplest states that can support certain forms of quantum computation, can be engineered by inducing superconductivity in a one-dimensional wire. As the experimental hunt for Majorana bound states intensifies, the question arises as to whether even richer ground states can be realized using the same synthetic approach. This proposal describes a route towards realizing such states in a newly discovered class of topologically ordered metamaterials known as fractional Chern insulators.  Remarkably, these class of metamaterials allow the requisite disparate properties to be engineered with single-site resolution in an artificial lattice, opening completely new design principles for quantum devices.  

Technical Abstract: in the last decade, the possibility of using ground state topological degeneracy as a basis for quantum computation has gone from being a distant dream to an ambitious but reasonable possibility.  Recent advances owe much to a shift in focus to a `synthetic' approach. Rather than seeking nonabelian anyons as elementary excitations in 'natural' electronic systems, the disparate ingredients required are assembled through proximity effects.  For example, Majorana bound state - the simplest nonabelian defect state - can be engineered by inducing superconductivity in an effectively spinless, one dimensional fermionic wire. As the experimental hunt for Majorana bound states intensifies, the question arises as to whether richer parafermion and Fibonacci anyon ground states can be realized using the same synthetic approach. This proposal describes a route towards realizing nonabelian defects in the recently discovered fractional Chern insulators in graphene heterostructures, including parafermion bound states.  Fractional Chern insulators are generalizations of fractional quantum Hall states to lattice systems.  Like conventional fractional quantum Hall states, the low-lying charged excitations of gapped fractional Chern insulators have anyonic statistics; however, the lattice degree of freedom endows them with new experimental tunability. Under the current proposal, we will classify fractional Chern insulator ground states in lithographically defined superlattices and use them to Engineer lattice defects and sublattice selective contacts for measurement-only braiding of nonabelian defect states.

por.por_cntn:
In the last decade, the possibility of using ground state topological degeneracy as a basis for quantum computation has gone from being a distant dream to an ambitious but reasonable possibility. Recent advances owe much to a shift in focus to a ‘synthetic’ approach. Rather than seek nonabelian anyons as elementary excitations in ‘natural’ electronic systems, the disparate ingredients required are assembled through proximity effects. For example, Majorana bound states—the simplest nonabelian defect state—can be engineered by inducing superconductivity in an effectively spinless, one dimensional fermionic wire. As the experimental hunt for majorana bound states intensifies, the question arises as to whether richer parafermion and Fibonacci anyon ground states can be realized using the same synthetic approach. These higher oprder topological defects are known to provide better protection from decoherence in a topological qubit, at the expense of placing even more stringent constraints on the substrate material that realizes them as elementary excitations.   

The goal of this project was to leverage our recent discovery of fractional Chern insulators in graphene heterostructures to engineer and detect nonabelian defect states, including parafermion bound states. Fractional Chern insualtors are generalizations of fractional quantum Hall states to lattice systems. Like conventional fractional quantum Hall states, the low-lying charged excitations of gapped fractional Chern insulators have anyonic statistics; however, the lattice degree of freedom endows them with new experimental tunability. However, in experimental realizations to date the lattice itself was fixed by the interference between two mismatched crystals, and could not be controlled with single site resolution.

This is a shame, as fractional Chern insulators in superlattice-patterned graphene devices may be an ideal platform for detecting and braiding nonabelian anyons, as simple lattice defects are sufficient to localize nonabelian defects—if a single lattice defect could be controlled, it could serve as an actuation knob for a topological qubit operation. This is in contrast to most fractional quantum Hall states, where localizing similar defects requires superconducting proximity effects, a materials science challenge. In a joint experiment-theory effort, we proposed to realize fractional Chern insulators in lithographically defined superlattices and use the resulting tunability to engineer and detect nonabelian defect states.

On the theoretical side, we started with an in-depth investigation of what is actually required to observe braiding of topological defects, the building block of a topological qubit.  We focused on mapping abstract theoretical arguments to a physically realizable system.  This effort resulted in a published theoretical paper where we mapped out some preliminary steps required for readout; however, the larger scale outcome of this work was that fractional Chern insulators may be quite a bit more difficult to use for topological quantum computing than anticipated—we discovered a number of previously unknown experimental requirements, which at current technology levels in our experimental platform of choice are not possible to realize. In parallel, we invested considerable effort into trying to implement superlattices on the 50 nanometer scale using conventional lithography. The reason to pursue this avenue is that by lithographically patterning the superlattice, we could both design the defects and individually actuate them.

These efforts also were not successful enough to merit continued study—we could not achieve the length scales for the superlattice size necessary while also preserving the materials quality necessary—introducing metal gates of any kind degrades the quality of pristine graphene samples beyond the desired threshold.  However, these efforts have born fruit in another respect, leading us to a new approach to designing local electrostatic potentials in ultra-high mobility graphene devices. This approach is based on patterning graphite gates with anodic oxidation lithography.  In this approach, a sharp and electrically conducting tip catalyzes oxidation and removal of graphite material on sub-100 nm length scales, and the patterned graphite flake is the incorporated as a field-effect gate into a multi-layer van der Waals heterostructures.  This approach has been revolutionary in preliminary tests, showing no sample degradation, and will enable a broad set of both fundamental and applied physics experiments on graphene heterostructures where nanoengineered potentials are desired.
